items.title: Build Routines That Boost Output
items.summary: Forget 5 AM miracle mornings. The best routines are the ones you actually stick to. Here's a flexible routine that keeps my output high—even on chaotic days: Start with a focus ritual: Mine is reviewing my 3 top goals for the day. Time-block deep work:…
items.content_html:
Forget 5 AM miracle mornings. The best routines are the ones you actually stick to. Here's a flexible routine that keeps my output high—even on chaotic days:

  • Start with a focus ritual: Mine is reviewing my 3 top goals for the day.

  • Time-block deep work: One 90-minute block is enough to move the needle.

  • Midday reset: A walk or quiet break clears mental fog.

  • End with a shutdown: I jot down tomorrow’s 3 priorities in Notion.

The key? Make it repeatable, not rigid. Your routine should support your energy, not drain it. Try tweaking yours to work with your natural flow—not against it.

items.title: My Weekly Workflow Stack
items.summary: Here’s my personal stack that keeps each week on track—from planning to execution: Notion: Weekly planner with tasks, goals, and reflections. Google Calendar: Time-block key projects and deep work. Toggl: Track where the time actually goes. Sunsama: Optional—pulls tasks and calendar together for daily focus.
items.content_html:
Here’s my personal stack that keeps each week on track—from planning to execution:

  • Notion: Weekly planner with tasks, goals, and reflections.

  • Google Calendar: Time-block key projects and deep work.

  • Toggl: Track where the time actually goes.

  • Sunsama: Optional—pulls tasks and calendar together for daily focus.

The workflow starts every Sunday with a 20-minute plan, then each tool supports a different layer: goals, time, and action. No overthinking—just systems that keep me moving.

items.title: Solo Founder Stack
items.summary: Running a business alone means tools are your team. Here's the exact stack I use as a solo founder: Framer: For building beautiful websites quickly. ConvertKit: For automations, sales emails, and list growth. TidyCal: For scheduling with clients or leads. Loom: Record and share walkthroughs…
items.content_html:
Running a business alone means tools are your team. Here's the exact stack I use as a solo founder:

  • Framer: For building beautiful websites quickly.

  • ConvertKit: For automations, sales emails, and list growth.

  • TidyCal: For scheduling with clients or leads.

  • Loom: Record and share walkthroughs or updates.

  • Notion: My brain, planner, and content hub.

Each tool replaces a role—designer, assistant, marketer. The key is picking tools that play well together and don’t overwhelm you. With this stack, I stay lean and move fast.

items.title: Ditch the Timesheet
items.summary: I used to lose hours trying to fill out timesheets. Then I found a better system. Here’s what I do now: Toggle Track: Simple timer with tags for clients/projects. Notion: Quick weekly breakdown of what got done. Auto-Reminders: I use a recurring task to review…
items.content_html:
I used to lose hours trying to fill out timesheets. Then I found a better system. Here’s what I do now:

  • Toggle Track: Simple timer with tags for clients/projects.

  • Notion: Quick weekly breakdown of what got done.

  • Auto-Reminders: I use a recurring task to review and log hours on Fridays.

Clients love the clarity. I love that I’m not chasing old notes to remember what I did. Plus, with Toggl reports, invoicing takes 2 minutes instead of 20. Ditch the manual grind—you’ll never go back.

items.title: How I Use AI to Save Time
items.summary: AI doesn’t replace my work—it supercharges it. Here’s how I use AI weekly to save hours and streamline my process: ChatGPT: For writing first drafts, brainstorming, and condensing notes. Claude: Great for summarizing long articles or PDFs. Grammarly: Final pass for tone, clarity, and typos.
items.content_html:
AI doesn’t replace my work—it supercharges it. Here’s how I use AI weekly to save hours and streamline my process:

  • ChatGPT: For writing first drafts, brainstorming, and condensing notes.

  • Claude: Great for summarizing long articles or PDFs.

  • Grammarly: Final pass for tone, clarity, and typos.

  • Notion AI: Helps generate structured outlines fast.

  • Perplexity: Quick research summaries that beat scrolling Google.

Each tool fits a specific role in my workflow, from ideation to polish. I stay in control, but I move much faster. Used right, AI becomes your smartest teammate.

items.title: How I Plan Weekly in 20 Minutes
items.summary: Every Sunday evening, I run a 20-minute ritual that keeps my week organized and intentional: Review the Past Week: Wins, blockers, loose ends. Pick 3 Goals: Not 10. Just the 3 outcomes that move the needle. Time Block: I block time in Google Calendar—especially for…
items.content_html:
Every Sunday evening, I run a 20-minute ritual that keeps my week organized and intentional:

  1. Review the Past Week: Wins, blockers, loose ends.

  2. Pick 3 Goals: Not 10. Just the 3 outcomes that move the needle.

  3. Time Block: I block time in Google Calendar—especially for deep work.

All of this lives in Notion, where I track tasks and update status daily. It’s fast, flexible, and powerful enough to keep me focused without overthinking it.

items.title: Set Boundaries With Tools
items.summary: Saying “no” is a skill—and tools can help you say it without friction. Here are 3 that reinforce boundaries and buy back your time: Calendly: Clients book only in your available slots—no back-and-forth. Email Templates: Keep responses firm but kind. Save time, avoid rewrites. Client…
items.content_html:
Saying “no” is a skill—and tools can help you say it without friction. Here are 3 that reinforce boundaries and buy back your time:

  • Calendly: Clients book only in your available slots—no back-and-forth.

  • Email Templates: Keep responses firm but kind. Save time, avoid rewrites.

  • Client Handbook: A Notion doc with FAQs, scope rules, and communication timelines.

These tools create structure and set expectations before problems arise. Set boundaries once, and let your tools do the rest.

items.title: Script Bank for Freelancers
items.summary: Freelancers wear a lot of hats—but communication is the one that gets ignored most. I’ve built a Notion doc with go-to client scripts that save me stress (and protect relationships). Late Payment Reminder: “Hi [Client], just checking in on the invoice from [date]. Let me…
items.content_html:
Freelancers wear a lot of hats—but communication is the one that gets ignored most. I’ve built a Notion doc with go-to client scripts that save me stress (and protect relationships).

Late Payment Reminder:
“Hi [Client], just checking in on the invoice from [date]. Let me know if anything’s holding it up.”

Scope Creep Check:
“That sounds great! I’ll send a revised proposal with that included.”

Welcome Message:
“Excited to work together! Here’s what to expect and how we’ll stay in touch.”

Templates like these help you stay cool, clear, and confident—especially under pressure.

items.title: 3 Tech Stacks That Run Businesses (2)
items.summary: Ever wonder what real creators and coaches use to run their businesses? I asked around—and these are actual tool stacks people rely on daily: Creator Stack Site: Framer Email: ConvertKit Scheduling: TidyCal Payments: Lemon Squeezy Freelancer Stack Portfolio: Notion Contracts: Bonsai Time Tracking: Toggl Invoicing:…
items.content_html:
Ever wonder what real creators and coaches use to run their businesses? I asked around—and these are actual tool stacks people rely on daily:

Creator Stack

  • Site: Framer

  • Email: ConvertKit

  • Scheduling: TidyCal

  • Payments: Lemon Squeezy

Freelancer Stack

  • Portfolio: Notion

  • Contracts: Bonsai

  • Time Tracking: Toggl

  • Invoicing: PayPal

Coach Stack

  • Landing Page: Typedream

  • Client Hub: Notion

  • Video Calls: Zoom

  • Email Campaigns: Loops

All in, each setup runs under $150/month—and earns far more.

items.title: Simple Project Tools
items.summary: Project management doesn’t need to be a second job. You can stay organized without heavy platforms. Here’s a setup I use for solo and micro-projects: Notion: Create task lists, store files, and centralize planning. Trello: Use Kanban boards for quick visual overviews. Slack or Discord:…
items.content_html:
Project management doesn’t need to be a second job. You can stay organized without heavy platforms. Here’s a setup I use for solo and micro-projects:

  • Notion: Create task lists, store files, and centralize planning.

  • Trello: Use Kanban boards for quick visual overviews.

  • Slack or Discord: Keep communications async and organized.

These tools are intuitive, low-maintenance, and easy to scale up or down. They help you stay focused on the work—without overcomplicating how you manage it.
